{{about| the semi-secret research subsidiary of [[Alphabet Inc.]]|the Canadian television series|X Company|the online banking company, [[X.com]]|PayPal|other uses|X (disambiguation)}} {{Use mdy dates|date=June 2017}} {{Infobox company | name = X Development LLC. | logo = Logo of X (company).svg | logo_size = 120px | type = [[Subsidiary]] of [[Alphabet Inc.]] | key_people = {{plainlist| * [[Astro Teller]] <small>([[Chief executive officer|CEO, "Captain of Moonshots"]])</small> }} | industry = [[Research and development]] | products = {{plainlist| * [[Artificial intelligence]] * [[Computational neuroscience]] * [[Health care]] * [[Biotechnology]] }} | services = | parent = {{plainlist| * [[Google]] (2010–2015) * [[Alphabet Inc.]] (2015–present) }} | divisions = | subsid = {{Collapsible list|framestyle = <!--(optional)-->|title=Subsidiaries|titlestyle = <!--(optional)-->|liststyle = <!--(optional)-->|1= [[Makani Power]]|2=SCHAFT|3=Industrial Perception|4=[[Redwood Robotics]]|5=[[Meka Robotics]]|6=Holomni|7=Bot & Dolly|8=Autofuss|9=Jetpac|10=Gecko Design|11=[[Flutter (company)|Flutter]]|12=DNNresearch|13=}} |former_name = Google X (2010–2015) | foundation = {{plainlist| * {{start date and age|2010|1}} {{small|(as Google X, under [[Google]])}} * {{start date and age|2015|10|2}} {{small|(as X, under [[Alphabet Inc.]])}} }} | founders = {{plainlist| * [[Sebastian Thrun]] * [[Yoky Matsuoka]] * [[Astro Teller]] }} | location_city = [[Mountain View, California]] | location_country = [[United States]] | homepage = [https://x.company/ x.company] }}
'''X Development LLC.''' (formerly '''Google X''') is an [[United States|American]] semi-secret [[research and development]] facility and organization founded by [[Google]] in January 2010,<ref>{{cite web|last= Rowan|first= David|title= Astro Teller of Google[x] wants to improve the world's broken industries|url= https://www.wired.co.uk/magazine/archive/2013/11/start/destination-moon|accessdate= January 25, 2014|date= October 31, 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title= Secret Google lab 'rewards failure'|url= https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/technology-25883016|work= Newsnight|publisher= BBC|accessdate= January 25, 2014|date= January 24, 2014}}</ref> which now operates as a subsidiary of [[Alphabet Inc.]]<ref>{{Cite web|title = Google to be publicly traded under Alphabet Inc. in planned restructuring|url = http://www.cbc.ca/news/technology/google-to-be-publicly-traded-under-alphabet-inc-in-planned-restructuring-1.3186244|accessdate = August 10, 2015}}</ref> X has its headquarters about a mile and a half from Alphabet's corporate headquarters, the [[Googleplex]], in [[Mountain View, California]].<ref name="businessweek1">{{cite web|last= Stone |first=B rad |url=http://www.businessweek.com/articles/2013-05-22/inside-googles-secret-lab |title= Inside Google's Secret Lab |publisher= Businessweek |date= May 22, 2013 |accessdate= May 26, 2013}}</ref><ref name="nytimes">{{cite news |title= Google's Lab of Wildest Dreams |first1= Claire |last1= Cain Miller |first2= Nick |last2= Bilton |url= https://www.nytimes.com/2011/11/14/technology/at-google-x-a-top-secret-lab-dreaming-up-the-future.html?_r=2|newspaper= The New York Times |date= November 13, 2011 |accessdate= February 23, 2012}}</ref>
Work at X is overseen by entrepreneur scientist [[Astro Teller]], as CEO and "Captain of Moonshots".<ref>{{cite web|title= Introduction to Project Glass|url= https://plus.google.com/111626127367496192147/posts/aKymsANgWBD|publisher= [[Project Glass]]|via= [[Google]]|accessdate= May 5, 2013|location= [[Google+]]|date =April 4, 2012|quote= "A group of us from Google[x] started Project Glass to build this kind of technology…"}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Shontell|first= Alyson|title= Meet The Mastermind Behind Driverless Cars, Glass And More: Google's 'Chief Of Moonshots,' Astro Teller|url= http://www.businessinsider.com/astro-teller-google-x-2013-9|work= Business Insider|accessdate=January 25, 2014|date= September 18, 2013}}</ref><ref name="fastco">{{cite web|last= Gertner|first= Jon|title= The Truth About Google X: An Exclusive Look Behind The Secretive Lab's Closed Doors|url= http://www.fastcompany.com/3028156/united-states-of-innovation/the-google-x-factor#1|work= Fast Company|accessdate= April 17, 2014|date= April 15, 2014}}</ref> The lab started with the development of [[Self-driving car project (Google)|Google's self-driving car]].<ref name="fastco" />
On October 2, 2015, after the complete restructuring of Google into Alphabet, Google X became an independent Alphabet company and was renamed to '''X'''.
On 25 October, 2018, ''[[The New York Times]]'' published an exposé entitled, "How Google Protected [[Andy Rubin]], the ‘Father of Android’". The company subsequently announced that "48 employees have been fired over the last two years" for sexual misconduct.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Welch |first1=Chris |title=Google says 48 people have been fired for sexual harassment in the last two years |url=https://www.theverge.com/2018/10/25/18024486/google-sexual-harassment-people-fired-rubin-2-years-ceo |accessdate=31 October 2018 |publisher=The Verge |date=25 October 2018}}</ref> A week after the article appeared, [[Google X]] executive Rich DeVaul resigned pursuant to a complaint of [[sexual harassment]].<ref>{{cite news |last1=Musil |first1=Steven |title=Google exec accused of sexual harassment leaves company |url=https://www.cnet.com/news/google-exec-accused-of-sexual-harassment-leaves-company/ |accessdate=31 October 2018 |publisher=CNET |date=30 October 2018}}</ref>
==Projects== X's mission is to invent and launch "moonshot" technologies that aim to make the world a radically better place.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://blog.x.company/a-peek-inside-the-moonshot-factory-operating-manual-f5c33c9ab4d7/|title=A Peek Inside the Moonshot Factory Operating Manual|last=|first=|date=2016-07-23|work=The Team at X|access-date=2018-04-24}}</ref> A moonshot is defined by X as the intersection of a big problem, a radical solution, and breakthrough technology.<ref>{{Citation|title=The unexpected benefit of celebrating failure {{!}} Astro Teller|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=2t13Rq4oc7A&feature=youtu.be&t=1m49s|language=en|accessdate=2018-04-24}}</ref>
===Glass=== [[File:Google Glass with frame.jpg|thumb|right|Google Glass with black frames for prescription lenses.]] {{Main article|Google Glass}}
Project Glass is a [[research and development]] program by [[Google]] to develop an [[augmented reality]] [[head-mounted display]] (HMD).<ref>{{cite news |url=http://money.cnn.com/2012/04/04/technology/google-project-glass/?source=cnn_bin|publisher=CNN |work=Money |title=Google unveils 'Project Glass' virtual-reality glasses |last=Goldman |first=David |date=April 4, 2012 |accessdate=}}</ref> The intended purpose of Project Glass products would be the hands-free displaying of information currently available to most [[smartphone]] users,<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.pcmag.com/article2/0,2817,2402613,00.asp |publisher=[[PC Magazine]] |title=Google 'Project Glass' Replaces the Smartphone With Glasses |first=Chloe |last=Albanesius | date=April 4, 2012}}</ref> and allowing for interaction with the Internet via [[Natural language processing|natural language]] voice commands.<ref>{{cite news |title=Google's 'Project Glass' Teases Augmented Reality Glasses |url=https://www.pcworld.com/article/253200/googles_project_glass_teases_augmented_reality_glasses.html |publisher=[[PCWorld (magazine)|PCWorld]] |last=Newman |first=Jared | date=April 4, 2012}}</ref> One Google Glass costs $1500.
===Makani=== Makani is a current project that was acquired by X in May 2013 designed to produce [[wind energy]] using [[kites]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.cnet.com/news/google-x-acquires-kite-power-startup-makani/|title=Google X acquires kite-power startup Makani|last=Shankland|first=Stephen|date=May 23, 2013|work=[[CNET]]|access-date=July 13, 2018|publisher=[[CBS Interactive]]}}</ref> The T-shaped planes are 85 feet wide and contain 8 turbines tethered to the ground.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2017-08-04/alphabet-s-green-energy-ambitions-hit-turbulence|title=Alphabet's Green Energy Ambitions Hit Turbulence|last=Bergen|first=Mark|date=August 4, 2017|work=[[Bloomberg News]]|access-date=July 13, 2018}}</ref> Compared to [[wind turbines]], Makani's kites require 90% less material.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://9to5google.com/2017/08/04/alphabet-x-clean-energy-moonshots/|title=Various clean energy moonshots at X have hit roadblocks, including Makani kite project|last=Li|first=Abner|date=August 4, 2017|work=9to5Google|access-date=July 13, 2018}}</ref> In December 2016, Makani's kite became the first energy kite in the world to generate electricity.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://renewablesnow.com/news/google-x-produces-1st-power-with-600-kw-kite-569167/|title=Makani produces 1st power with 600-kW kite|last=|first=|date=May 18|work=Renewables Now|access-date=July 13, 2018|url-access=limited}}</ref>
=== FSOC === X is currently conducting tests of [[free-space optical communication]] (FSOC) in rural areas of India.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/business/alphabets-x-provides-high-speed-internet-without-fiber-in-ap/articleshow/63023268.cms|title=Alphabet’s X provides high-speed internet without fiber in AP|last=Phadnis|first=Shilpa|date=February 22, 2018|work=[[The Times of India]]|access-date=July 21, 2018}}</ref> The technology uses light beams which are developed by X's office in [[Visakhapatnam]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.hindustantimes.com/india-news/google-x-ready-to-set-up-development-centre-in-visakhapatnam/story-2jJvBpUwjwCQhjHGsOsFsM.html|title=Google X ready to set up Development Centre in Visakhapatnam|date=December 15, 2018|work=[[Hindustan Times]]|access-date=July 21, 2018}}</ref> As of December 2017, X had set up 2,000 of these units in India, through a partnership with [[Andhra Pradesh State FiberNet Limited]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://qz.com/1157941/google-x-will-use-light-beams-to-bring-the-internet-to-12-million-households-in-indias-andhra-pradesh-state/|title=Alphabet’s X will use light beams to bring the internet to millions of rural Indian households|last=U N|first=Sushma|date=December 15, 2017|work=[[Quartz (publication)|Quartz]] India|access-date=July 21, 2018}}</ref>
===Barge=== In October 2013, the existence of four [[Google barges]] was revealed, with the vessels registered under the [[dummy corporation]] ''By And Large''. Two of the barges have a superstructure whose construction has been kept under the utmost secrecy, while speculations indicate they could be used as marketing for, and stores for, Google Glass. However, these are merely speculations. Others have suggested that it might be used as a floating data center.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.theverge.com/2013/10/31/5051642/google-plans-to-dock-mystery-barge-at-former-army-post-in-san |title=Google plans to dock mystery barge at former Army post in San Francisco |author=Casey Newton |publisher=[[The Verge]]}}</ref>
===Graduated projects=== ====Waymo (self-driving car)==== [[File:Waymo self-driving car side view.gk.jpg|thumb|A Waymo self-driving car on the road in Mountain View.]] {{Main article|Waymo}}
Waymo was a project by [[Google]] that involves developing technology for [[driverless car]]s. In December 2016, Google transitioned the project into a new company called Waymo, housed under Google's parent company Alphabet. The project was led by Google engineer [[Sebastian Thrun]], director of the [[Stanford Artificial Intelligence Laboratory]] and co-inventor of [[Google Street View]]. Thrun's team at Stanford created the robotic vehicle [[Stanley (vehicle)|Stanley]] which won the [[2005 DARPA Grand Challenge]] and its {{USD|2 million}} prize from the [[United States Department of Defense]].<ref name="NYT2010">{{cite news|author=[[John Markoff]]|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/10/10/science/10google.html|title=Google Cars Drive Themselves, in Traffic|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=October 9, 2010|accessdate=October 11, 2010}}</ref> The team developing the system consisted of 15 engineers working for Google, including [[Chris Urmson]], Mike Montemerlo, and [[Anthony Levandowski]], who had worked on the [[DARPA Grand Challenge|DARPA Grand]] and [[DARPA Urban Challenge|Urban]] Challenges.<ref name="Google">{{cite web|author=Sebastian Thrun|url=http://googleblog.blogspot.com/2010/10/what-were-driving-at.html|title=What we're driving at|publisher=The Official Google Blog|date=October 9, 2010|accessdate=October 11, 2010}}</ref>
The U.S. state of [[Nevada]] passed a law in June 2011 concerning the operation of driverless cars in Nevada. Google had been lobbying for driverless car laws.<ref name="GCC0611">{{cite web|url=http://www.greencarcongress.com/2011/06/ab511-20110625.html|title=Nevada enacts law authorizing autonomous (driverless) vehicles|last=|first=|date=June 25, 2011|website=|publisher=Green Car Congress|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|accessdate=June 25, 2011}}</ref><ref name="Forbes0611">{{cite news|url=https://blogs.forbes.com/alexknapp/2011/06/22/nevada-passes-law-authorizing-driverless-cars/|title=Nevada Passes Law Authorizing Driverless Cars|author=Alex Knapp|work=[[Forbes]]|date=June 22, 2011|accessdate=June 25, 2011}}</ref><ref name="NYT0511">{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/05/11/science/11drive.html?_r=1&emc=eta1|title=Google Lobbies Nevada To Allow Self-Driving Cars|author=John Markoff|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=May 10, 2011|accessdate=May 11, 2011}}</ref> The license was issued to a Toyota Prius modified with Google's experimental driver-less technology.<ref name="1stLicense">{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2012/05/08/uk-usa-nevada-google-idUSLNE84701320120508|title=Google gets first self-driven car license in Nevada|author=Mary Slosson |work=[[Reuters]]|date=May 8, 2012|accessdate=May 9, 2012}}</ref> {{As of|2016|03}}, Google had test driven their fleet of vehicles, in autonomous mode, a total of {{convert|1498214|mi|abbr=on}}.<ref>{{cite web|title=Google Self-Driving Car Project Monthly Report - March 2016|url=https://static.googleusercontent.com/media/www.google.com/lt//selfdrivingcar/files/reports/report-0316.pdf|publisher=Google|accessdate=March 23, 2016}}</ref>
====Loon==== [[File:Google Loon - Launch Event.jpg|thumb|A Project Loon research balloon.]] {{Main article|Loon (company)}}
Project Loon was a project of X that aims to bring internet access to everyone by creating an internet network of balloons flying through the [[stratosphere]]. It uses wireless routers in balloons that are above weather and plans to give access to the internet to those who can't reach it or are in need of help.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.google.com/loon/|title=Official website of project Loon}}</ref> In July 2018, Loon graduated from X and was made a subsidiary of Alphabet.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.inc.com/thomas-koulopoulos/the-moonshot-to-create-next-google.html|title=The Moonshot to Create the Next Google|last=Koulopoulos|first=Thomas|date=July 2018|work=[[Inc. (magazine)|Inc.]]|access-date=July 13, 2018}}</ref>
====Wing==== {{Main article|Wing (company)}} Project Wing was a project of X that aims to rapidly deliver products across a city by using flying vehicles, similar to the [[Amazon Prime Air]] concept.<ref>{{Cite journal|magazine=AOPA Pilot|date=April 2015|page=63|title=Droning On}}</ref> At the time of the announcement on August 28, 2014, it had already been in development secretly at Google for about two years, with full-scale testing being carried out in Australia. The flying vehicles take off vertically, then rotate to a horizontal position for flying around. For delivery, it hovers and winches packages down to the ground. At the end of the tether is a small bundle of electronics which detects that the package has hit the ground, detaches from the delivery, and is pulled back up into the body of the vehicle. Dropping the cargo or landing were found to be unfeasible, as users compromised the safety.<ref name=gra1>Warwick, Graham. "[http://aviationweek.com/technology/google-details-project-wing-unmanned-package-delivery-rd Google Details 'Project Wing' Unmanned Package-Delivery R&D]" ''[[Aviation Week & Space Technology]]'', November 3, 2014. Accessed: November 5, 2014. {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141105011555/http://aviationweek.com/technology/google-details-project-wing-unmanned-package-delivery-rd |date=November 5, 2014 }} on November 5, 2014</ref>
====Others==== {{columns-list|colwidth=120em|}} * The [[Google Contact Lens]], a smart contact lens that aims to assist people with diabetes by constantly measuring the glucose levels in their tears, was announced by Google on January 16, 2014.<ref name="GoogleBlog">{{cite news |title=Introducing our smart contact lens project |url=https://googleblog.blogspot.com/2014/01/introducing-our-smart-contact-lens.html |date=January 16, 2014 |accessdate=July 31, 2016}}</ref> This project, the nanodiagnostics project<ref name="Wired">{{cite news |title=Why Google's Cancer-Detecting Pill Is More Than Just Hype. |url=https://www.wired.com/2014/11/googles-cancer-detecting-pill-just-hype/ |date=November 5, 2014 |accessdate=July 31, 2016}}</ref> to develop a cancer-detecting pill, and other life sciences efforts are now being carried out by [[Verily]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.solveforx.com/graduated|title=Official website of X}}</ref> * [[Google Brain]] is now a [[deep learning]] research project at [[Google]] which started as an X project. Considered one of the biggest successes,<ref name="NY Times Business">{{cite news |title=They Promised Us Jet Packs. |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/07/24/technology/they-promised-us-jet-packs-they-promised-the-bosses-profit.html?ref=technology&_r=1 |date=July 23, 2016 |accessdate=July 31, 2016}}</ref> this one project has produced enough value for Google to more than cover the total costs of X, according to Astro Teller.<ref name="NY Times Bits">{{cite news |title=Astro Teller, Google's 'Captain of Moonshots,' on Making Profits at Google X |url=http://bits.blogs.nytimes.com/2015/02/16/googles-captain-of-moonshots-on-making-profits-at-google-x/?_r=0 |date=February 6, 2015 |accessdate=July 31, 2016}}</ref> * Dandelion<ref>[https://dandelion.co/ Dandelion official site]</ref> was spun out as a company not under the Alphabet umbrella, aiming to sell geothermal energy systems to consumers.<ref>[http://www.businessinsider.com/alphabet-x-spins-out-geothermal-energy-company-dandelion-2017-7 Google's parent company spun out a new business that heats your home with geothermal energy]</ref> * Google Watch * Gcam * [[Verily]] * Project Insight * [[Project Tango]] * Flux * [[Daydream View]] * [[Chronicle (company)|Chronicle]]
===Explorations=== {{columns-list|colwidth=120em| * Foghorn, a project to produce liquid hydrocarbon fuel for vehicles using sea water as a source of carbon dioxide, extracted using membrane technology, and also as a source of hydrogen, using electrolysis. The project was killed by X in 2016 and the results published in 2018.<ref>https://x.company/explorations/foghorn/</ref> * Calcifer explored using lighter-than-air vehicles to move freight at lower cost in countries with poor transportation infrastructure. Abandoned in 2014 due to the high cost of prototyping and limited expected impact.<ref>https://x.company/explorations/</ref> }}
===Other projects=== {{columns-list|colwidth=120em| * The [[web of things]], a way of connecting real-world objects to the Internet.<ref name=nytimes /> * Long lasting smartphone batteries.<ref name="nytimes3">{{cite news |title=Google's X lab is working on batteries that last longer |url=https://www.engadget.com/2015/04/11/google-battery-tech/|newspaper=WSJ |date=April 11, 2015 |accessdate=November 11, 2015}}</ref> * Malta, an energy storage concept that uses a [[heat pump]] to charge both hot (salt) and cold (antifreeze) reservoirs when renewable energy is available and then use the temperature difference between the reservoirs to generate electricity as needed at other times.<ref>https://x.company/explorations/malta/</ref> * FSOC Free Space Optical Communications, a spin-off from Loon that uses lasers to communicate through the air over relatively long distances. A pilot project is planned for [[Andhra Pradesh]] state in India.<ref>https://blog.x.company/exploring-a-new-approach-to-connectivity-861a0159f63e</ref><ref>http://www.business-standard.com/article/companies/google-s-x-labs-to-share-fsoc-technology-for-andhra-s-fiber-grid-117121500451_1.html</ref> }}
Projects that X has considered and rejected include a [[space elevator]], which was deemed to be currently infeasible;<ref>{{cite web|last=Gayomali|first=Chris|title=Google X Confirms The Rumors: It Really Did Try To Design A Space Elevator|url=http://www.fastcompany.com/3029138/world-changing-ideas/google-x-confirms-the-rumors-it-really-did-try-to-design-a-space-elevat?partner=rss|work=Fast Company|accessdate=April 17, 2014|date=April 15, 2014}}</ref> a [[hoverboard]], which was determined to be too costly relative to the societal benefits;<ref>{{cite web|last=Gayomali|first=Chris|title=This Is Why We Don't Have Google X Hoverboards Yet|url=http://www.fastcompany.com/3029162/most-innovative-companies/this-is-why-we-dont-have-google-x-hoverboards-yet|work=Fast Company|accessdate=April 17, 2014|date=April 15, 2014}}</ref> a user-safe [[jetpack]], which was thought to be too loud and energy-wasting;<ref name="rejects">{{cite web|last=Mack|first=Eric|title=Four Crazy Google X Projects That Failed|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/ericmack/2014/05/06/four-crazy-google-x-projects-that-failed/|work=Forbes|accessdate=May 9, 2014|date=May 6, 2014}}</ref> and [[teleportation]], which was found to violate the laws of physics.<ref name="rejects" />
==Approach== In February 2016, Astro Teller, the X "Captain of Moonshots", gave a [[TED (conference)|TED talk]]<ref>{{cite web|title=The unexpected benefit of celebrating failure|url=http://www.ted.com/talks/astro_teller_the_unexpected_benefit_of_celebrating_failure|work=TED|accessdate=June 3, 2016|date= Feb 2016}}</ref> in which he described the X approach to projects. Unusual characteristics of the approach included constantly trying to find reasons to kill off projects by tackling the hardest parts first, and both celebrating and rewarding staff when projects were killed off due to failure.
On May 17, 2018, an internal video entitled ''The Selfish Ledger'' was leaked by [[The Verge]], regarding reshaping society through total data collection. A spokesperson stated that "This is a thought-experiment by the Design team from years ago that uses a technique known as ‘speculative design’ to explore uncomfortable ideas and concepts in order to provoke discussion and debate. It’s not related to any current or future products."<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.theverge.com/2018/5/17/17344250/google-x-selfish-ledger-video-data-privacy|title=Google’s Selfish Ledger is an unsettling vision of Silicon Valley social engineering|work=The Verge|access-date=2018-05-19}}</ref>
==Subsidiaries== A number of companies [[List of mergers and acquisitions by Google|have been acquired and merged]] into X, covering a diverse range of skills including [[wind turbines]], [[robotics]], [[artificial intelligence]], [[humanoid robot]]s, robotic arms, and [[computer vision]]. In 2013, X acquired [[Makani Power]], a US company which develops tethered wings/kites with mounted wind turbines for low cost renewable energy generation.<ref>{{cite web|title=Google acquires kite-power generator|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/technology-22636565|work=BBC News|accessdate=May 23, 2013}}</ref> In 2014, it acquired product design and mechanical engineering firm Gecko Design, whose previous products included the Fitbit activity tracker and low-cost computers.<ref name=":0" /> As of 2015, X has acquired 14 companies: among them are [[Redwood Robotics]], [[Meka Robotics]], [[Boston Dynamics]], and Jetpac.<ref name=":0">{{cite web|last1=Miners|first1=Zach|title=Google acquires Gecko Design for next-generation products|url=http://www.pcworld.com/article/2598100/google-acquires-gecko-design-for-nextgeneration-products.html|accessdate=August 22, 2014|date=August 22, 2014}}</ref> In June 2017, X sold Boston Dynamics to [[SoftBank Group]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.latimes.com/business/technology/la-fi-softbank-20170609-story.html|title=Why Google wanted to sell – and Softbank wanted to buy – Boston Dynamics, which makes crazy robots|last=D'Angelo|first=Alexa|date=June 9, 2017|work=[[Los Angeles Times]]|access-date=June 9, 2017|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}}</ref>
==Campus== A reporter from ''[[Bloomberg Businessweek]]'' visited the site in 2013 and described it as "ordinary two-story red-brick buildings about a half-mile from Google's main campus. There's a burbling fountain out front and rows of company-issued bikes, which employees use to shuttle to the main campus."<ref name="businessweek1"/>
